managed database and so it manages capacity for you all the time you you
know you start using the table and your throughput goes up your application is doing work DynamoDB really can can scale
up can scale down to meet the demands of your application so in June we
introduced this thing called Auto scale basically you create a table Auto scale is on by default and then you basically
set it and forget it and as the demands of your application goes up dynamo
scales up as the demands of the application comes down dynamic scales down so basically you pay for what you
really need with respect of capacity and you really don't have to spend too much time managing capacity we also
introduced this thing called time to live which is a at ETL where you can set
expiry time for items in the database so if you have tables that are infinitely growing and you get to a point where you
think that you really don't need data from five years ago you can set it TTL and data will automatically expire in
the background for you so you can shrink your tables and and and save on your storage costs or you can keep the data
forever your choice we introduced VP C so that
you can include DynamoDB tables in your Virtual Private Networks for better
security and as you may know dynamo is also integrates with AWS aims so you can
have fine-grained access control so now with VP C and fine-grained access control you get a very good set of
capabilities for managing the security of your tables we also introduced Dax
which is the dynamo DB accelerator it's a caching mechanism it's fully integrated into dynamodb and one of the
nice things about it is it you don't actually have to be fully aware that cash sitting in front of the database
because you basically point your application to Dax and all the rights go through the cash and all the reads come
from the cash and with that you can get microsecond response times because it's an in-memory store for for dynamo so if
you need caching to to meet the demands of really high read rates Dax is really
good for that so that's the stuff that's already been introduced over the last few months and as you heard today we've
announced global tables and again this is in response to a lot of our customers who are building applications to to

globally dispersed user base where everybody can read and write from where
they are and Dynamo is really truly the the first multi master and multi region
database because your rights are done locally they're not routed to some primary or some master someplace on the
globe where then everything gets replicated from we actually do reads and writes locally and dynamodb in the
